content.webTitle: England get up to speed by unleashing May, Watson and Daly on Wallabies

fields.headline: England get up to speed by unleashing May, Watson and Daly on Wallabies
fields.bodyText: Everyone agrees top-level rugby is getting quicker and England are now maintaining the trend. Rarely have they ever had a sharper back three than the trio facing Australia on Saturday, with Mike Brown’s concussion having offered Jonny May, Anthony Watson and Elliot Daly the chance of a collective gallop at Twickenham. Not since Delon Armitage, Paul Sackey and Ugo Monye played in a comfortable England win against the Pacific Islanders in autumn 2008, with a youthful Danny Cipriani at fly-half, has there arguably been anything as swift. Before that – and with no offence to the World Cup winners Josh Lewsey and Jason Robinson – it is probably necessary to go back to 2001 when Iain Balshaw, in company with Dan Luger and Ben Cohen, showed Wales a clean pair of heels in a 44-15 win in Cardiff. Assuming England obtain enough ball, there must be a chance of fireworks after the damp squib against Argentina last week. With the distinctly rapid Semesa Rokoduguni on the bench alongside Danny Care and the fleet-footed Sam Simmonds, there is certainly the potential for several fresh jolts of electricity. Clearly that has to be allied to gainline power but Eddie Jones is among those excited by the possibilities. “Watson’s like a Maserati, mate, he flies. He’s an absolute flyer,” the England head coach said. “I thought he was one of the best players on the Lions tour. We’re disappointed Mike’s not playing but it’s a great opportunity for Anthony. Jonny’s strong, he’s fast and he’ll be the fastest winger on the field. Any opportunities he gets, he’ll turn into points for us.” In addition to May’s striking domestic form for Leicester – he has scored 10 tries in his first nine games for the club – Australia may also be concerned to discover the winger has just broken his own personal best for flat-out sprinting since returning from the tweaked hamstring which ruled him out of contention for the Pumas game. The 27-year-old was timed at 10.49 metres per second on the grass of Twickenham last Saturday morning, a result which took even him by surprise. “It was a 40- or 50-metre sprint, a rehab run. I was shocked,” May said. “I didn’t think I would go anywhere that fast. I knew I had to run flat out to test it and was pretty nervous but it was fine. Everyone is getting stronger and faster and that’s the approach I’ve wanted to take [since] I blew my knee out in January 2016. When your speed gets taken away from you, it makes you hungrier than ever to get quicker.” Given May was hardly slow beforehand – his scintillating try against New Zealand three years ago was certainly a classic of the genre – it is a timely example of why England’s captain, Dylan Hartley, believes May’s thirst for improvement is good for the entire squad. “Jonny’s fast, real fast,” Hartley said. “The way he prepares is unbelievable, he’s a 24/7 athlete. Everything he does is to make sure he’s the fastest winger in the world. Other players see that and think: ‘If he’s like that then I need to be.’ It rubs off on people.” Hartley also rates Daly’s mental alertness – “He’s sharp up there, too” – but the absence of Brown will be a culture shock given the Harlequin has started 20 of the 21 Tests since Jones became England’s head coach. “It’s the first game any of us have played without him at full-back, barring one or two games,” May said. “It’s an exciting back three but we’ll miss Brownie. I’m sure he’ll be back next week but it gives us an opportunity for Anthony to have a go at full-back and that excites us as well.” On this occasion May will switch to the right wing, with Daly on the left, although the former is not hugely bothered by the move. “I’ve played on the left wing mainly because I preferred the number 11 to 14. I just prefer odd numbers to even ones. It makes complete sense for Elliot to be on the left wing because he’s left‑footed. We have spoken about Australia’s kicking game and we want to put pressure on that. Hopefully we will get some good opportunities to run the ball back at them.” The return of Owen Farrell relegates Henry Slade to the bench, with Joe Launchbury and Courtney Lawes paired in the second row and Maro Itoje also among the replacements. Itoje is eager to feature but Jones is determined not to over-play his Lions contingent. “The number of players who have suffered long-term injuries from the Lions tour is significant. Maro and Owen are now approaching their best [but] the others are miles away from their best. “This is going to be a difficult period of time for us and we have to mix and match. We’ll need to take other players out at certain times to recondition them because we’re moving towards the World Cup. We need players to be fit. If we get long-term injuries in 2018 it affects our ability to play in the World Cup. We’re getting close to that.” England (v Australia) A Watson (Bath); J May (Leicester), J Joseph (Bath), O Farrell (Saracens), E Daly (Wasps); G Ford (Leicester), B Youngs (Leicester); M Vunipola (Saracens), D Hartley (Northampton, capt), D Cole (Leicester), J Launchbury (Wasps), C Lawes (Northampton), C Robshaw (Harlequins), S Underhill (Bath), N Hughes (Wasps). Replacements J George (Saracens), J Marler (Harlequins), H Williams (Exeter), M Itoje (Saracens), S Simmonds (Exeter), D Care (Harlequins), H Slade (Exeter), S Rokoduguni (Bath).
